Message.Title: Repatriating Apple's Assets
Message.Msg: Apple has approx $95 billion in marketable assets offshore. To get it back to the States, the company would need to pay corporate taxes. Some believe Apple is waiting for a tax holiday. What if - instead - they offered the government a deal? Apple sets up a 10% fund (or $9.5 billion) to establish a tuition-free math and science university for the best and brightest US students. Call it Apple University or iU. For Apple, they get not only an enormous amount of goodwill but an incredible feeder program for R&D and talent. And for the U.S., we have a university dedicated to capturing American talent that matches the employment needs of our country...right now there are 3 million tech job OPENINGS due to the mismatch of tech job requirements vs. applicants' qualifications. Just an idea, but I thought a message board could be a creative forum to discuss its merits and flaws.

Message.Title: Anyone down in AAPL want to take a look at a highly underpriced high growth stock according to its P/E/G (est. 400% growth rate plus)
Message.Msg: #$%$ is experiencing a fairly consistant growth rate of around 443% which would place its PEG value at above $2.50 per share if its PEG were at 0.5 (typically considered to be about half priced and a very strong buy), the thing is though MJNA's price isn't $2.50, it isn't even $1.50, or even $1.00. Currently MJNA's share price is $0.41 and advancing rather fast, where rather fast is incredibly fast (already up several hundred percent just in months). Just saying, MJNA is in play, its way underpriced according to P/E /G and on February 17th the company is making its first year ahead projections. MJNA just did an audit on its last quarter's earnings, is in the process of further auditing, and intends to uplist soon. Its multi-national, operates legally, and is worth looking at. I hold a long position in it, but if its price simply gets to a PEG of 0.5 that would be a 600% return and it would still appear to be half priced given a P/E/G of 1 to be fair. The company is expanding rapidly, so most believe my 443% growth rate estimate will end up being blown away even if various countries and the economy in general goes into deep recession. Just a friendly heads up. The MJNA message board on Yahoo! is very active, and very positive (some state they won't sell under $5 per share if ever).

Message.Title: BlackBerry Loses Another Big Customer to Apple -HD
Message.Msg: BlackBerry (NASDAQ: BBRY ) has received the technological boot from Home Depot. The company will no Home depot will no longer be utilizing BlackBerry OS, which is going to be replaced with Apple's (NASDAQ: HD switching to AAPL ) iOS. Store managers and all corporate-level employees have already begun the process of switching over to the iPhone 4S. Across the company, this opportunity is worth around 10,000 phones for Apple. In September 2012, Immigration and Customs Enforcement ditched over 17,600 BlackBerry devices for iPhones . Defense Department Information Systems Agency took BlackBerry off its planned mobile device purchases, which at first involves over 162,000 devices (including the iPhone) and has the potential to grow to 8 million devices. CNBC and the News Media are not reporting the real facts concerning AAPL taking over the Corporate World.

Message.Title: Apple's (AAPL) 'iWatch' Could Add Up to $4/Share Annually - Analyst
Message.Msg: Morgan Stanley's Katy Huberty is out with a few comments and estimates on the potential for iWatch sales. Notably, Huberty discloses that she has no specific knowledge of the iWatch or its potential features, but is modeling based on market analysis. Huberty sees the iWatch adding about $10 billion to $15 billion in incremental revenue, leading to $2.50 to $4 of additional EPS annually.

Message.Title: Tim, here's a global opportunity...
Message.Msg: Italian Senate Approves Plastic Bag Sanctions Significant Revenue Opportunity Expected From Italy and Other European Nations That are Exploring Similar Sanctions EL SEGUNDO, Calif., Feb. 12, 2013 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Cereplast (CERP), a leading manufacturer of proprietary biobased, compostable and sustainable bioplastics, is pleased to announce that the Italian Senate approved the legislation that mandates the discontinuation of traditional single-use plastic bags in favor of bioplastic bags or other alternatives, and penalizes those who continue to use traditional plastic bags. Senator Francesco Ferrante announced the approval of the Application Decree last week stating, "Finally, we will make Italy the first plastic-free European country for the single-use plastic bag sector." The Decree has been signed by the Ministers and is currently undergoing the proper administrative process toward formal publication. The sanctions will then become effective and applicable 60 days from publication. Merchants must make the switch to biodegradable and compostable bags and stop using traditional single-use plastic bags within 60 days from the date of publication, or sanctions for non-compliance will be enforced. The fines for non-compliance range between EURO2,500 and EURO25,000, and may be increased up to four times the maximum violation if it applies to large quantities of bags, or if the value of the goods exceeds 20% of the total use of the offender. Italian Minister of the Environment Corrado Clini stated, "The opinion expressed by the Senate is an important step to actually make our country plastic-free. We will constantly monitor compliance to ensure that this objective can be achieved quickly and effectively." The Application Decree specifies the following: • Disposable bags used for the removal of goods must be compostable in accordance with the European standard for compostability: EN 13432:2002 • Reusable bags with an external handle that are composed of polymers tha

So those who would rather run a company like Samsung who success solely relies on being able to skirt IP laws with their copycat products and yet cannot match the quality of Apple's hardware, has to rely on another company for software (Google's android) and will now have a bulls-eye on its back for its unfriendly behavior towards it competitors (many of whom are customers in other markets). Message.Title: Analyst: Here’s Apple’s $80 Billion Opportunity
Message.Msg: With a new high-definition television product and a rumored smart watch, Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) can generate more than $80 billion in global incremental revenue, Morgan Stanley’s Katy Huberty wrote in a bullish note on the company on Tuesday. The analyst added that the current drop in the company’s share price was factoring in a deceleration in revenue and earnings growth that was unjustified in light of medium- and long-term growth drivers. Apple now is a once-in-a-decade buying opportunity. According to Huberty, Wall Street was pricing in negative 4 percent long-term earnings per share growth in the stock, even though Apple has been achieving 14 percent revenue growth. “In other words, investors expect significant share losses and/or margin contraction,” she wrote. “In addition to iPhone market expansion through new products and carrier partners, Apple’s entry into new markets can help shift investor perception of long-term growth.”Huberty estimated that Apple could earn $17 billion in annual revenue and $4.50 per share earnings if it were to launch a smart TV in the U.S. at an average selling price of $1,300. That would come from a barely 10 percent penetration of the half a billion active iTunes account users, and could go up to as much as $68 billion and $18 in EPS if the launch is turned global.

Message.Title: VERY BULLISH
Message.Msg: Things are moving pretty quickly over in Cupertino, it seems, and Cook is extremely bullish. Here are a few other takeaways from the keynote: Retail is still a major focus. Cook says when he’s sad, he goes to Apple stores because they’re “like Prozac,” and the experience is just as important as being able to close on sales. The Apple Stores averaged more than $50 million revenue in the last year, he said. He said Apple this fiscal year plans to make 20 stores bigger and add 30 more around the world. Specs don’t matter. When asked about competing phones with bigger screens, sometimes called “phablets,” Cook dismissed the notion of competing solely on screen size, saying the experience and the quality of the device — and that Aha! moment — is more important. He said consume electronics makers invent new specs because their products don’t have a great experience. “Do you know the speed of an AX processer? You probably don’t. Does it matter? You want a fantastic experience.” Halo effects matter. The iPad Mini has a thinner margin than the iPad, but it’s important to get it into the hands of consumers because that would prompt them to buy other products, Cook said. “When we looked at iPad, what you would find when you looked at some data, you would find that over 50% of the people in countries like China and Brazil that were buying an iPad don’t own an Apple product,” he said. Services are also important. Cook spent a lot of time explaining that Apple wasn’t just a hardware company: It has software and services too. Here’s the money quote: “Last quarter, if you looked at our software and services revenue, it was $3.7 billion. If you look at that versus software and services companies, that’s an incredible amount of revenue.” There’s an enormous amount of head room for smartphones. Of the 500-something million smartphones in the ecosystem, 40% of that arrived in the last year. But if Apple were going to build a cheaper iPhone, it wouldn’t just make a product that wasn’t

Message.Title: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Looking To Make Big Acquisitions: Tim Cook
Message.Msg: "Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) chief executive, Tim Cook said, while speaking at the Goldman Sachs Technology and Internet Conference, that his company is looking to make some blockbuster acquisitions. But none of the companies Apple considered for acquisition could pass its tests. Cook assured investors that the company will keep looking at a large target company. On an average, the iPhone maker has acquired one company every other month, to add intellectual property and smart people under its umbrella. But, most of those purchases have been very small. Tim Cook said when looking for an acquisition, Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) likes to control the primary technology, not just the product. He said Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) is not under pressure to go acquire revenues. Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)’s avoidance of large deals has helped the company stay away from the pitfalls that other tech companies with large acquisitions have faced. ”We want to make great products — if a large company could help us do that even better, then that’s of interest,” said Cook. Tim Cook revealed that Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) has distributed a whopping $8 billion to app developers. He said the company has “enormous momentum” in the tablets and smartphone markets. And the primary reason behind that is the ecosystem around its devices. ”We built an ecosystem that is the best customer experience on the planet,” Cook said. He added that Apple App Store has recorded over 40 billion downloads, about half of that coming in 2012 alone!"

Message.Title: It is being reported that Cook shreaded Einhorns preferred share proposal..
Message.Msg: Nothing of the kind happened. Cook said the proposal was quote " innovative" . He merely scoffed at the lawsuit because he claimed it was caused by a misunderstanding about prop 2. He also said ithe lawsuit was a sideshow that was wasting company money and that if Prop 2 were inacted it would in no way prevent the issuance of preferred shares. It would only give the shareholder the right to vote on such a proposition if the board felt it was worthy. The bottom line is if you read that Cook destroyed any chance of a preferred stock issuance ,he did no such thing and he made it clear that the Board is looking at ALL ways to return capitol. I read that as to say that the additional return of capital is not if but how and how much.

Topic.Title: Motley Fools

Message.Msg: I subscribe to 3 newsletters. Had many homeruns with them and the newsletters paid for themselves 1000's fold. Got in CMG at 47. ISRG also under 50. You just cannot follow every recommendation blindly in their paid newsletters. Use them as prospecting. Buy what you know or understand and leave the rest behind. I've crushed it using their picks but mostly because I am selective. I've also missed some of their other homeruns simply because I thought the stocks were overvalued or I did not fully understand the business. This caused me from missing a few more 10 bagger plus picks but doesn't matter if you get 10 bagger plus with 1 stock or pick 10 that all go 10 bagger. Your money still goes up

Message.Title: Apple dividend increase more likely after Cook talk: PiperJaffray analysts
Message.Msg: Stock traders appear not to have liked Tim Cook’s comments Tuesday, sending shares down as the Apple CEO spoke at an investment conference, but analysts at PiperJaffray have a different take. Gene Munster and Douglas Clinton are out with a quick react to Cook’s remarks, saying they have two key takeaways on Apple AAPL-1.28%: • We have greater confidence that there will be a slight increase to the dividend when Apple reports the March quarter. • We continue to expect Apple will have a cheaper iPhone related product. We are modeling for this in the September 2013 quarter The analysts have an overweight rating and a price target of $767 on Apple shares

Topic.Title: Motley Fools

Message.Msg: Well they do not have paid newsletters like MF so not fully comparable. However some of their paid writers have some decent analysis. I think there are alot of novice investors out there. My advice is to use sites and services like prospecting tools. Never take at face value what they say as being right or wrong. Evaluate all their arguments bullish and bearish yourself and draw your own conclusion. Then either take action or don't accordingly. Remember Buffett says there are NOT 3 strikes in investing. You can wait for a great pitch as long as it takes. Could be days, weeks, months and even sometimes years (as in the bubble of 2000..nobody should have been buying then).

Topic.Title: SZYM ready to replicate the same growth AAPL just had

Message.Msg: Solazyme, Inc. (NASDAQ: SZYM), a renewable oil and bioproducts company, and Mitsui & Co., Ltd. announced today that they have entered into a $20 million multi-year agreement to jointly develop a suite of triglyceride oils for use primarily in the oleochemical industry. The agreement includes further development of Solazyme’s breakthrough high myristic algal oil, a valuable raw material in the oleochemical industry, as well as additional oils that Solazyme is developing for the oleochemical and industrial sectors. Product development is expected to span a multi-year period, with periodic product introductions throughout the term of the joint development alliance. End use applications may include renewable, high-performance polymer additives for plastic applications, aviation lubricants, and toiletry and household products. “Mitsui’s extensive knowledge of the end use markets for the jointly-developed triglyceride products, including both the oleochemical industry and applications further downstream, makes Mitsui an ideal fit for Solazyme,” said Jonathan Wolfson, CEO, Solazyme. “We look forward to rapid progress on our research and development efforts, and to commercialize these novel products thereafter.” “Collaborating with Solazyme allows us to develop highly attractive products to penetrate the traditional oleochemicals industry, and expand beyond the supply limitations caused by both regional oil production and constraints in conventional oil profiles. Solazyme’s flexible manufacturing process and oil tailoring capabilities helps to support long-term competitiveness, independent of price swings inherent to this industry, while allowing us to produce tailored oils that are in demand in the marketplace,” said Mr. Daiji Kojima, General Manager of Specialty chemicals Division, Mitsui. “Mitsui looks forward to strengthening its position in the oleochemicals industry through the successful development and commercialization of these novel products as a potential sou

Message.Title: Q: What are you most proud of in your first year? Surely Not Giving Back $250B Market Cap?
Message.Msg: in the history of this "Great Game" has a company ever lost as much shareholder capital? Q: What are you most proud of in your first year? Cook: I'm incredibly proud... I'm most proud of our employees. They're there to do not only that great work, but the best work in their lives. They're there to do it without limits, they're the most creative in the world. It's a privilege. I'm incredibly proud of the products, we have the best smartphone on the market, we have the best tablet on the market, we have the best digital music player on the market. For those things we elect to do, and we continue to focus on a few, they're really great. I'm incredibly bullsih about the future and what Apple can do and more contributions it can make to the world. I'm very proud that we're out front, that we have a spine on supply responsibility. I'm incredibly proud that we're doing heavy lifting with the environment, that we're eliminating toxins. I'm proud we have the largest private solar farm anywhere, that we can run our data centers on 100% renewable energy. I don't mean to gush, but it's how I feel. It's the privilege of a lifetime and humbling.

Plus phase III trials were highly successful and their efficacy trials have been published in JAMA. Market cap is currently 154 Million and their sales are projected to be between 300-500 Million in their first year. Many reasons to believe stock should run-up as we approach April - they have an excellent narrative since their delivery mechanism eliminates concerns of abuse which has been a rampant problem with methadone, oxycodone, etc. --- all distributed in pill form. Because probuphine (TTNP's drug to battle opiod addiction) is administered through a rod injected below the skin and is released consistently over a six-month period, this eliminates opportunities for abuse and other criminal behavior that comes with alternatives for battling drug addiction. Do your due diligence on this, I think it is a buy since TTNP's technology is likely to become gold standard for opiod addiction and because the delivery mechanism could have applications for other drugs...

Topic.Title: AAPL PRICE TARGET: 750!

Message.Msg: Apple is making more money than anyone else. They have more money in the bank too!!! They will announce an increase in the dividend and also stock buy backs when they report their huge earnings. Anyone who bets against them will lose allot of money. Anyone shorting this stock is just plain stupid. They have the fundamentals that everyone else wants to have I am so sick of reading idiotic comments about how this company is going down. No basis for that at all. Huge revenues and they are containing and reducing costs. Business is still expanding and they are going to reach out to lower incomes in the third worlds with cheaper phones that will be gobbled up like crazy. Billions and billions of dollars will be made from these sales and they will then be looking to buy other apple products. Just like in the USA. They. will want the best or as close to it as they can afford. When they increase the dividend it will attract thousands and thousands of value investors to buy into this amazing company. Although growth will not be as huge as it has been the last few years they will still maintain some and the huge business they have in place will continue to return great profits making it a safe and secure investment while still having growth potential. Innovation and development of new products could still spur this company into another growth cycle if they do come up with some new big products. This is still very possible with all of the development people they employ and their huge resources. This could easily go to 800 dollars this year and I expect that it will easily make it back to 700 without a problem.

Message.Title: Tim Cook says Retna is better than OLED?
Message.Msg: What a *&^%^& IDIOT! Samsung is kicking iPhone's #$%$ and he's just being STUPID! Guess which product won the Best of the Show in CES this year? LAS VEGAS--CNET's team of crack technology editors argued long into the Vegas afternoon yesterday, painstakingly honing hundreds of cumulative man- and woman-hours of CES 2012 coverage into 10 category winners and, finally, one product sharp enough to earn Best in Show: the LG 55EM9600. It's a TV. And its organic light-emitting diode display technology is the future of flat-panel tech. OLED promises better picture quality than either plasma or LCD/LED--thanks to effectively infinite contrast (for realzies this time!), wide viewing angles and lightning-fast response times--combined with an unbelievable form factor. The winning LG measures just 4mm in depth, "three credit cards thick" as LG's Tim Alessi cooed accepting the award, and boasts a bezel around the screen just 1mm wide. It's basically all gorgeous picture. If AAPL is win the phone war, they HAVE to us OLED on their iPhone line and give the consumers more size choices. All of my iPhone friends have switched to Galaxy S III or Note 2 in last 2 month including my wife and I. OLED on Note 2 is #$%$ AWESOME!! iPhone 5 is STALE and BORING!!

Message.Title: QUALCOMM Downgraded By JP Morgan On Smartphone Adoption Slowdown
Message.Msg: JPMorgan Downgrades Qualcomm (QCOM) to Neutral; Prepare for Smartphone Adoption Slowdown (Updated - February 12, 2013 9:29 AM EST) JPMorgan downgraded Qualcomm (NASDAQ: QCOM) from Overweight to Neutral with a price target of $70 telling investors they should brace for slowing smartphone adoption. "We are downgrading our rating on Qualcomm from Overweight to Neutral as every day in 2013 brings us closer to rapidly slowing smartphone adoption that we expect in 2014, analyst Rod Hall said. "As the windfall from high 28nm chip demand recedes into the rearview mirror we believe this eventual market deceleration is likely to become more of a focus for Qualcomm investors." The firm sees 37% smartphone growth in 2013, although they see growth slowing to 17% in 2014. The firm's proprietary models also suggests that 3G ASPs are likely to finally begin declining this year as cheaper tablets and smartphones weigh into the mix. The firm sees limited upside to current earnings estimates and the stock price. The firm's FY13 EPS estimate for QCOM comes down by 1% to $4.53 from its prior $4.59.

Message.Title: Intel Breakout ALERT! Pops over forty day average on Intel TV
Message.Msg: and rumored tender of netflix. the market wanted apple to make a move here but @ the goldman snacks conference today apple's ceo said they have NO INTEREST in a growth by acquisition strategy. so the market will now bid up front-runner intel on netfix growth speculation. "Q: In the past, you've done a handful of deals a year. Is there something in Apple's culture that turns you against the concept of large acquisitions? Cook: If you look at the last 3 years, we've averaged about an acquisition every other month. They're companies where they have really smart people, and, or, IP. Generally speaking we've been in many cases taken something that they're working on and move the skills to work on something else. Great example: we bought a company a few years ago and we were in the process of building our capability to design the engines that are in all of today's iPhones and iPads. This was an incredibly skilled group of guys, and they could supplement an incredible group of folks and they were working on PowerPC at the time. We didn't have an interest in that, so we moved the skills to work on our iPhone and other engines. We will do more of those. We have looked at large companies. In each case, it didn't pass our test. Will we look at more, I think so. But we're disciplined and thoughtful, and we don't feel a pressure to go out and acquire revenue. We want to make great products. If a large company could help us, then that would be of interest. But again, deliberate, thoughtful, is our mantra."

Topic.Title: Bought 100 $490 calls

Message.Msg: OK You stepped up and put up $6500. IF the stock hits 485 tomorrow you MAY double that IF you sell. But you won't because IF it hits 485 then you will want to hang in for the big score. That Means you run with it til Friday. But then you will need 490.65 to break even. Guess what. Look at every Friday for last several weeks. The price is always pinned almost to the penny to a $5 increment. If the trading gets around $485 then look for a pin at $480 and you are out. And if it is trading somewhat higher then the pin will go to $485 and you are still out and same for $490. So what will move the stock up between now and Friday over $22 ? ? ? Timid Cook sitting next to Michelle my Belle ? If you truly feel that Apple will rise from this point by Friday then buy $470 calls. You will definitely get a good return even with a Pin at 480 and will only lose if it falls from here, which you clearly believe will not happen. Although you won;t have a 100 contracts if you just get to the breakeven point of your 490s each contract you do get will be in the money over $2000. Look at the option at EOD. Your $490 is at .50 the $470 is at $4.20 So your $6500 is already lost $1500 . However you could have had appx 11 contracts of 470 . Hitting your 490's break even point would return back $22000 while the 490's are still worthless. I spent the time to go through this so you and everyone else can get a perspective on this whole mess. I sure your mileage may vary. I wish the best to all long short or sideways.

Message.Title: Name some other mega-cap companies and tell me what they have in commom
Message.Msg: They are monopolies. Apple sells phones, phones folks, not oil,food, etc. Their operating system isn't on 90% of pc's (softy), they don't handle 80% of global searches (goog). Slap an 8 multiple on $30 and you get $240 by 2015. Add to that the fact that revenues will be sliding, it's entirely possible we see a $150-$180 print if we go into a recession/ depression. Face the facts folks, the iphone no longer has the cool factor, it's not trendy, Samsung is!

Message.Title: "I can't comment" on Apple acquisition
Message.Msg: The entire tech industry is on high alert surrounding Apple’s iWatch and the potential for creating an entire new ecosystem on wearable technology. In fact, the CEO of Pebble, a new smart watch company, was recently asked if his company has been approached by Apple for potential acquisition talks. It seems totally viable, especially if Apple wants to enter the space. Pebble’s CEO gave a somewhat esoteric response: “I can’t comment on that,” he said, according to CNBC. Surely if Apple wasn’t in some form of talk to acquire the company, the CEO might publicly disclose that talks weren’t ongoing. Or maybe he wants his investors to think there’s a possibility, especially if he wants additional investments in the future. Still, we wouldn’t be surprised if there were some sort of talks and we’ll be watching this closely.

Message.Title: Sold last bit of Apple
Message.Msg: I asked myself below question. Apple's market cap is 439 billion. Apple's cash is 137 billion. Ex cash, it is valued at 302 billion. Apple, from profit perspective is a 2 product business iphone and ipad Forget about cash for a moment , would you really value 2 product company $302 billion ? Not only that, there are going to be at least 2 phones in the market that are better than iphone - Sony Xperia and Blackberry Z10, Tablet market is slowly getting commoditized too. Even if you give 100 billion valuation to ipad,, You have to ask yourself, Would you really value a company that makes iphone at $202 billion? I know I will get a lot of heat from this post, but like everybody long, I was in love with Apple's cash. Once you take the cash out, you can see it clear one way or the other.

Topic.Title: So is

Message.Msg: Sure, Cook is not the visionary Steve Jobs was ... there is no replacement for Steve. That doesn't doom Apple, however. Cook is just one of many employees there, they still have great employees and great products (and more to come). Cook is doing OK IMO. He could be *much* worse. Sure, he could be more political to help "juice" the stock price - he is instead very stubbornly dedicated to Steve Jobs' principles w/ regards to not shirking on product Quality (and making sure that everything they do, they do best). Remember, Steve Jobs hand-picked Cook as his replacement. Anyways, so you don't like the guy because he doesn't goose the stock for you so you can take your short-term gains ... just hold, Apple still has good growth ahead, the stock will do fine over the long-term. I expect by the end of 2013 we will see $550/share.

Topic.Title: I have lost all confidence in Tim Cook

Message.Msg: Tim Cook put that bozo Einhorn in his place. Again, David Einhorn is projecting Apple's stock performance onto Tim Cook. Look, people had LONGSTANDING positions that they decided to unload. The shareholder base is churning ... as it does when ALL companies start to experience slowing growth. Tim Cook has done the absolute right thing, in that he has maintained razor sharp focus on the company's vision and has not hastily released products or made knee jerk reactions amidst the stock slide. Give the guy and his visionary team the benefit of the doubt or sell your shares. Really, those are your *only* two choices. Armchair quarterbacking, with virtually no inside information, is so lame. Apple has begun to attack potential goldmine markets like India and Russia, and they'll soon ink their China Mobile deal. Couple that with the imminent release of iTV (or whatever it'll be called) and iRadio, and you'd be foolish to bet against a company printing a NET PROFIT of 800 million to 1 billion dollars PER WEEK. People are just taking the churning of the shareholder base far too passionately. There have been days that it bothered me, but I've learned to separate my emotions from the fantastic job the company is doing of ***making money.***

Topic.Title: The narrative on AAPL is so over-the-top negative, it is absolutely comical

Message.Msg: I agree. I listened to the presentation live. I heard his comments on the lawsuit and, you are correct, the comments are being misrepresented to continue the negativity. Along with that, the address was optimistic and completely consistent with Apple's style. There was nothing there today to result in a 2.5% haircut. $6 of that came in 1 minute and another $7 in another two quick drops of less than 5 minutes. This is not something that I am worried about at all. Unfortunately, for those that are long, we are in "show-me" mode and the stock will only react when the company shows that its death is greatly exaggerated. The good news is that, in my opinion, the stock takes off after the next earnings reports no matter what is reported. The expectations has been lowered that much. I am long and giving it 24 months. In the meantime, I will continue to take advantage of the options premiums and trade the covered calls against my position weekly. In a few months, my investment should have a cost-basis of zero.

Message.Title: New Apple Commercial
Message.Msg: The commercial opens showing a line of Hedge Fund managers marching in unison through a long tunnel monitored by a string of telescreens. This is in sharp contrast to the full-color shots of the nameless runner wearing an athletic "uniform" a white tank top with a cubist picture of Apple’s iPhone , a white sweat band on her left wrist, and a red one on her right), and is carrying a large brass-headed hammer. As she is chased by the Fast Money Crew and Jim Cramer (presumably agents of the CNBC Thought Police) wearing black uniforms, protected by riot gear, helmets with visors covering their faces, and armed with large night sticks, she races towards a large screen with the image of Melissa Lee, also seen on the telescreens earlier) bashing Apple. The runner, now close to the screen, hurls the hammer towards it, right at the moment Melissa Lee announces, "Samsing shall prevail!" In a flurry of light and smoke, the screen is destroyed, shocking the people watching the screen.

Message.Title: AMZN gets the high valuation because of market share but no profits
Message.Msg: NFLX gets the high valuation because of presumed forays into new revenue streams. GOOG gets a high valuation for high market share and the speculation of dabbling in new markets. FB gets high valuation because of potential in new markets and tons of users. AAPL? Crushes AMZN where it matters most - PROFITS. I don't care if you have $10T in revenue if you break even. AAPL? Compared to NFLX and NFLX's the risk of becoming obsolete due to very low barriers to entry, a declining subscriber base, a shift in technology away from its revenue stream that is difficult to compete (Mail DVDs)? Come on. I cannot find one compelling reason that NFLX should be valued at a valuation 60X of AAPL. You read that right! 60X. AAPL? Compared to GOOG? This, to me is the ONLY valid comparison in the group. Yet, when I see GOOG at twice the valuation of AAPL vs. earnings, I wonder why the risks to GOOG are ignored. The risk of having market share numbers that have nowhere to go but down. The risk of advertising moving to mobile where the profits and revenues are smaller. The risks of an Android OS that will have many competitors in the coming years due to its success. The risk of no innovation (sound familiar?) other than lab prototypes like google glass. AAPL? Compared to FB? Lots of users? Apple has that too, but with the added bonus that apple actually makes money from their user base. We give FB the assumption that they will be able to monetize social media to a level to justify $50-$100B valuation? Why? No one has been able to yet? Losing its cool? FB is losing more than just cool. They are losing their cool and users to Twitter and anyone other hot thing coming up. But let's ignore that too, shall we. The point is, the negatives being SPECULATED about AAPL can be found in all the darling stocks of wall street. Ignore this noise and see what AAPL the company is doing. Products, stores, software, services, innovation and most of all TONS OF PROFITS.

Topic.Title: Spoiler alert: I'm buying more Apple

Message.Msg: Getting back to Apple's future profitability, there is real risk -- as there is with any company. I can't predict what the future holds, but I like the odds we're getting with Apple at current prices. At $475 a share, its trailing P/E ratio is 10.5. Factoring in that cash hoard in its entirety, it drops to 7.2. If you prefer free cash flow to net income, those multiples are even a bit lower. Those are the multiples that a lagging, second-tier company deserves -- not a revolutionary, best-in-class company with three-year compounded sales and EPS growth rates north of 50%. Like In-N-Out Burger or the Beatles, Apple creates things that people line up for. Unlike just about every other large company on the planet, Apple's having trouble making its products fast enough to meet consumer demand. Apple's also a company that has a huge opportunity in the TV space in addition to the 18% sales growth it posted on its current lineup of smartphones, tablets, and computers. Can you imagine? A company that has too much cash, too much demand for its products, and legitimate areas for growth trading at dirt cheap earnings multiples? I like these odds, and I'm buying more Apple.

Message.Title: What's an Einhorn to do? SELL! He needs to cut and run
Message.Msg: Einhorn should simply vote with his wallet. Nobody putting a gun to his head forcing him to own apple shares. He is in the classic investing conundrum. Stick with a ticker until you get back to break even or hope for your exit at the high watermark. Well Apple does not care about shareholders. It is not their game plan nor motivation. If you want a company that will share the bounty with you Apple has NEVER been the place for this (meaning buybacks or dividends). Without capital allocation a stock certificate is just like gold. You hope to god somebody will be dumb enough to pay you more for it than you bought it for! Apple shareholders now realizing they have paper and not many fools out there willing to pay more for it than they did. They realize the other avenue for profit (i.e. sharing the wealth) which is dividends of a substantial kind is not going to happen. Partly because apple just does not care. Partly because they won't bring back cash from overseas and get it tagged 35%. So Einhorn should do what I did. Sell. I did it right on the conference call. Had no issue with the numbers. However on the call when asked what they were doing with the cash and I got no dividend boost then or buyback I hit the sell button. Apple should have done this months ago. Now it is too late. The stock is broken. Psychology is broken. Charts are broken. Confidence in the CEO, CFO, board and the team there is broken. Like Buffett says it takes a lifetime to earn people's trust and 15 minutes to lose it completely. Cook made the mistake thinking he was above Wall Street. Well Wall Street bleeds to main street and vice versa. Now things don't look so bright. Sell it Einhorn and move on. I did. I have to say it is nice to see the other co's I invested in going up rather than riding the pain train that is Apple. I got a nice hit on KORS today. PM was a nice winner which got some of my proceeds when I dumped apple. ABV was another.

Message.Title: Obama Lying Sack of #$%$! Spineless!
Message.Msg: Three years after the White House arranged a hero's welcome at the State of the Union address for the Fort Hood police sergeant and her partner who stopped the deadly shooting there, Kimberly Munley says President Obama broke the promise he made to her that the victims would be well taken care of. "Betrayed is a good word," former Sgt. Munley told ABC News in a tearful interview to be broadcast tonight on "World News with Diane Sawyer" and "Nightline." "Not to the least little bit have the victims been taken care of," she said. "In fact they've been neglected." There was no immediate comment from the White House about Munley's allegations. Thirteen people were killed, including a pregnant soldier, and 32 others shot in the November 2009 rampage by the accused shooter, Major Nidal Hasan, who now awaits a military trial on charges of premeditated murder and attempted murder. Tonight's broadcast report also includes dramatic new video, obtained by ABC News, taken in the immediate aftermath of the shooting, capturing the chaos and terror of the day.

Topic.Title: First time in four years and regretably so, I'm out....

Message.Msg: I bought in 2006 ($60/share basis), and finally sold my shares after the last conference call. After the stock had been kicked in the teeth for 3 months, that was the time to defend it, during Apple's traditionally strongest earnings call of the year. It was a time for bold action, and Cook was meek and clueless. The stock's current malaise is a delayed grief response to the loss of Steve Jobs. He was our Edison, Ford and PT Barnum rolled into one, and he was the definition of irreplaceable. I have nothing personal against Cook, but he does not strike me as any more or less able than countless other tech CEO's.

Topic.Title: Looks like it is Time to Bet against Apple

Message.Msg: Actually, the 5 min SMA crossover works equally well on both long and short side. You need to look at a longer trend line (say 5 to 10 days) to decide which side to trade. You trade long on up trend and short on down trend. Also pay attention to key support and resistance levels. Whatever system you use, make sure you keep disciplined. The key of day trade is to take advantage of intraday swing and avoid after market risks. So make sure you close all your positions at the end of every trading day, no exception.

Message.Title: Bloodbath in Aapl!
Message.Msg: The last, but by no means least, of today's laggards is Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL ) , the globally recognized technology giant that briefly held the title as the largest company in the world last year. The stock fell 2.5% after a lengthy speech by CEO Tim Cook at a technology conference left investors worried Cook didn't have his head on straight about shareholder value. Cook was rather frank, saying that hedge fund manager David Einhorn's proposal for a perpetual 4% dividend was "a waste of shareholder money." Reading between the lines of Cook's talk today, one UBS analyst said it sounded as if Apple was gearing up to market a low-end phone, and that margins could be pressured as a result. There's no doubt that Apple is at the center of technology's largest revolution ever and that longtime shareholders have been handsomely rewarded, with more than 1,000% gains. However, there is a debate raging as to whether Apple remains a buy. The Motley Fool's senior technology analyst and managing bureau chief, Eric Bleeker, is prepared to fill you in on both reasons to buy and reasons to sell Apple and what opportunities are left for the company

Message.Title: Is the $137 bil really there?
Message.Msg: Most of this money is in oversea bank accounts in low tax jurisdictions or tax havens. If they repatriate it back to the U.S. to pay dividends etc, they will have to pay taxes on it. So the $137bil that always reported is not really $137bil but a fraction of that. Apple not alone hires child labour in China but also don't pay their taxes. Shame on them.

Message.Title: Mr. Cook & Apple vs "the Sharks"
Message.Msg: I do not believe anyone on this message board has experienced or can conceive of the constraints on Mr. Cook when speaking in public or even privately to stock analysts, shareholders, commentators and the media. His every word is being scrutinized by the SEC, lawyer sharks, competitors and governments around the world. His legal team must be advising him to say nothing but if he must every word needs to be reviewed from 360 degrees by all sorts of advisors. So I give him credit for being so open in his remarks today. Apple is under legal pressure to use its' "cash". As shareholders or outsiders, we have no idea what plans, strategies, R&D projects, acquisitions etc are being discussed internally at the highest levels within Apple. Only Mr. Cook and the BOD can allocate assets and "cash" effectively knowing Apple's plans and the competive landscape. If outside legal pressure or stock price pressure force management to modify their plans the company will be more and more short term focus and knee jerk reactionary. This is not what made Apple great and what will make it a profitable for us long term shareholders in the future. Coercing assets to be diverted to increased dividends or stock buybacks may be detrimental to future growth and profitallity. If the BOD, on the other hand, deems such action is in the best long term interest of all Apple stakeholders (employees, customers, shareholders, suppliers) that is a completely different thing. As far as I am concerned Apple has more value than is reflected in its current share price and I would think Apples' internal discounted cah flow valuation, if we could see it, would be considerable greater. So I would suggest we cut Mr. Cook some slack and then after three years at the helm then evaluate his performance as we are expecting long term returns.

Topic.Title: Vote no on AAPL prop.#2

Message.Msg: A yes vote on proposal 2 is to eliminate the Blank Check prefered stock. This means that if prop2 passes, that the BOD would not be able to issue preferred stock without shareholder voted approval. If prop2 doesn't pass, the BOD could at any time issue preferred stock without shareholder approval. Cook, the BOD and I all are not interested in a preferred stock therefore recommend a vote FOR prop2. If Apple decides to gives cash to shareholders, I'd like to see the cash paid by increasing the regular dividend over the next few years. This would make the yields for common AAPL shareholders look very attractive. I oppose the preferred stock because I'd have to sell Apple common shares and would not trust Apple to look out for the interests of Apple shareholders.

Message.Title: Wi-Fi + Cellular Models of iPad mini & Fourth Generation iPad Available in China This Friday
Message.Msg: BEIJING-- Apple® today announced the Wi-Fi + Cellular versions of iPad® mini and the new fourth generation iPad with Retina® display will be available in China on Friday, January 18. iPad mini and the fourth generation iPad are currently available in more than 100 countries worldwide including the US, Australia, Canada, China, France, Germany, Japan and the UK. iPad mini is a completely new iPad design that is 23 percent thinner and 53 percent lighter than the third generation iPad, and features a stunning 7.9-inch Multi-Touch" display, FaceTime® HD and 5 megapixel iSight® cameras, ultrafast wireless performance* and an incredible 10 hours of battery life. ** The fourth generation iPad features a gorgeous 9.7-inch Retina display, new Apple (AAPL)-designed A6X chip, FaceTime HD camera and ultrafast wireless performance*. Both iPad mini and the new fourth generation iPad come with iOS 6. iPad mini with Wi-Fi + Cellular models come in black & slate or white & silver for a suggested retail price of $459 (US) for the 16GB model, $559 (US) for the 32GB model and $659 (US) for the 64GB model. The fourth generation iPad with Wi-Fi + Cellular models come in black or white for a suggested retail price of $629 (US) for the 16GB model, $729 (US) for the 32GB model and $829 (US) for the 64GB model. Additionally, iPad 2 is available at just $399 (US).

Message.Msg: I used to hold AAPL stock long term, began being a shareholder in 2004. Following Jobs passing it became evident that AAPL was a swing or day trade. The cost of $ was the determinant for me. I could swing AAPL stock on a weekly basis and garner the same return as leaving it alone for 3 weeks. While there are those that see AAPL going to 320-360, I see that as rather absurd. 420-425 may well be here prior to Q2 earnings. What chaps my hiney as this point is the obscene cash hoard AAPL is cowering over like Montgomery Burns. Heck, Homer could find a complimentary company to acquire. AAPL is ubitquous. On one hand they tout social responsibility in the work force, yet on the other they shun any obligation to their share holders. This is the oxymoron for which I detest the ground on which Cook trods. Let Odummer nominate Cook for Ambassador of North Korea. Maybe Samsung would kidnap him and pry loose "chock full pipeline" AAPL has on deck. I say horse hockey. Jobs wouldn't have tolerated "when I want to get it done" performance. Cook is a bloated cow that needs to be sent to slaughter.
